gov.ornl.keva.core

Class BloomFilter

  • java.lang.Object
    • gov.ornl.keva.core.BloomFilter

  • public class BloomFilter
extends java.lang.Object
    A bloom filter is a space efficient datastructure used to test membership against some set of data. The interesting property of bloom filters are that the false negative rate is zero, but there is a small false positive rate. That means that if the filter returns "true" for some membership, the data may not actually reside in the set, but we need to perform a more expensive test to find out.
    Author:
    James Horey

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      BloomFilter()
      Create a default bloom filter with reasonable settings.
      BloomFilter(double fpRate, int expected)
      Create a bloom filter for the number of items expected and the false positive rate.

      • contains

        public boolean contains(byte[] data)
        Indicate whether this item is contained in the filter. Bloom filters have a false positive rate, so a True value does not necessarily mean that the item is actually in the set, but simply that it has a high probability of being in the set.
        Parameters:
        data - Data element we are searching for.
        Returns:
        True if the element might be found. False otherwise.

        Clear the filter.
